Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Bidart Bros has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Bidart Bros, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Bidart Bros has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name              | Process Chemical              | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration       Anhydrous Ammonia               32,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations

as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

Process Chemistry



The refrigeration system employed at Bidart Brothers is a flooded system.



In this system, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to multiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator feeds multiple bunker mounted/ceiling suspended evaporator coils located in the refrigerated zones. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it travels back to the accumulators, through a suction return line, and into the main suction accumulator. Any remaining liquid falls to the bottom of the vessel and is fed by gravity into the transfer vessel. Inside the transfer vessel, the liquid rises in temperature and is returned to the high pressure receiver as high pressure liquid. From the main suction accumulator, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the reciprocating/screw compressors.

 

The system also includes direct expansion (DX) ceiling suspended evaporator coils. In DX evaporators, high pressure liquid is supplied from the high pressure receiver directly to the evaporators. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporators. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low te

mperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporators and is returned to the main suction accumulator.



The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to the evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condenser uses air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating.

 

Safety Systems



The machinery room is equipped with two (2) ammonia detectors. A Drager PointGard 2100 provides concentration detection and alerts personnel if the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm. The Drager PointGard 2100 activates audible/visual alarms outside the machinery room. A Honeywell detector provides concentration detection at 25 ppm and notify facility personnel through an auto-dialer. Additionally, there are three (3) Honeywell and three (3) Maraco standalone detectors that provide concentration detection at 25 ppm which will alarm and notify facility personnel through an auto-dialer.



The sample system is equipped with an ammonia detector, vacuum pump, and tubing which extends to the rooms where air is sampled. The vacuum pump is used to draw air through the tubing into the detector. On 10 minute intervals, the system toggles from one sample point to the next. The sample system provides ammonia detection to non-machinery rooms as summarized below:

CA Rooms Sample System

CA Rooms 1-18



The sampling system/ammonia detector is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm and will activate an audible/visual alarm and notify plant personnel of the situation through

the auto-dialer. 



The machinery room is equipped with two (2) roof-mounted normal ventilation fans that are continuously running during seasonal operation. Additionally, they serve as emergency ventilation fans in case of an ammonia release within the machinery room. The emergency ventilation system can be controlled manually by the push button outside the principal machinery room door located inside the Emergency Control Box.



The Emergency Control Box was installed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2 and the Fire Code at the time of construction.  The control box contains three (3) valves.

Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve

Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system.  Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system.  Opening Valve #3 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system.  



The Emergency Control Box is seldom used in a refrigeration system, but has been installed for rare emergency situations.



Each Screw Compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment.



The Reciprocating Compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment.



All ASME vessels are equipped with Pressure Relief Valves.  The high side of each system relieves at 250 psig while the low side of each system relieves at 150 psig.  All Pressure Relief Valves vent to the atmosphere.



All pressure relief devices are piped to a diffusion tank sized according to the Uniform Mechanical Code at the time of construction. This tank helps mitigate many of the hazards associated with the release of ammonia through a pressure relief valve.



The Main Suction Accumulator is equipped with a High Level Float Switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation.  This prevents liquid ammonia from

entering the compressor.

 

Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Bidart Brothers consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Bidart Brothers is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Bidart Bros has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Bidart Bros facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.  



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Bidart Bros has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Bidart Bro's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency

Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Bidart Bros has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Bidart Bros continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Bidart Bro's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Bidart Bro's management team can ensure that the RMP-P

SM program is being implemented.



Bidart Bros has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Bidart Bros has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Bidart Bros now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Bidart Bros employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Bidart Bros will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
